Efficient hydrogen production by methanol aqueous phase reforming over KMnO4 modified PtMnK/AC catalyst: Regulating the hydrophilicity of carbon support Peng Wang Writing – original draft Investigation a Yuankai Huang Investigation Formal analysis a Riyang Shu Validation Resources a Junyao Wang Visualization Validation Methodology a Jianping Liu Supervision Project administration a Chao Wang Supervision Funding acquisition a Zhipeng Tian Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition Conceptualization a b ⁎ Ying Chen Project administration Supervision a a Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Functional Soft Condensed Matter, School of Materials and Energy, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou 510006, PR China Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Functional Soft Condensed Matter School of Materials and Energy Guangdong University of Technology Guangzhou 510006 PR China aGuangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Functional Soft Condensed Matter, School of Materials and Energy, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou 510006, PR China b Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of New and Renewable Energy Research and Development, Guangzhou 510640, PR China Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of New and Renewable Energy Research and Development Guangzhou 510640 PR China bGuangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of New and Renewable Energy Research and Development, Guangzhou 510640, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author at: Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Functional Soft Condensed Matter, School of Materials and Energy, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou 510006, PR China. Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Functional Soft Condensed Matter School of Materials and Energy Guangdong University of Technology Guangzhou 510006 PR China The production of hydrogen through the aqueous phase reforming of biomass-derived oxygenates has broad application prospects in distributed hydrogen energy systems. Activated carbon is commonly employed as a catalyst support in catalytic aqueous phase reforming due to its high surface area and hydrothermal stability. Nevertheless, its hydrophobicity hinders the efficient adsorption of water molecules, which affects the activity of the aqueous phase reforming reaction. In this study, catalysts using carbon as support with varying hydrophilicity were synthesized using nitric acid and potassium permanganate as modifiers. The efficiency of these catalysts was then examined in the aqueous phase reforming reaction of methanol and the water gas shift reaction, respectively. The impact of the hydrophilicity of the support on the reaction performances was examined with diverse characterization techniques. The results demonstrated that the PtMnK/AC catalyst exhibited 1.2 times the hydrogen production yield compared to the conventional Pt/AC catalyst, indicating that enhancing the hydrophilicity of the support promoted the water gas shift reaction while limiting methanation side reactions in methanol aqueous phase reforming. The effective interaction between hydrophilic surfaces and oxygen vacancies enhances the catalyst's capability to dissociate H2O and react with CO* intermediates to generate more hydrogen, which is regarded as the rate determining step of methanol aqueous phase reforming. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Aqueous phase reforming Hydrophilicity Carbon support Water gas shift reaction Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Advancing clean energy represents a practical strategy to achieve both "emission peak" and "carbon neutrality." Furthermore, hydrogen generated from clean energy is highly efficient when converted into electricity through proton exchange membrane fuel cells [1,2]. However, the distinctive physical properties of hydrogen make its storage and transportation expensive [3]. Biomass can be pyrolyzed to produce high-value bio-oil fuels, and during the refining process, large quantities of waste streams containing oxygen derivatives are produced, which are underutilized and pose a threat to the environment [4,5]. Therefore, the production of hydrogen from catalytic aqueous phase reforming of oxygenate solutions is an economical and reliable method that has been widely investigated [6,7]. As one of the most concentrated compounds in the water obtained from the pyrolysis of biomass, methanol contains only C-H, C-O and O-H bonds, which can be used as a model compound in exploring APR reaction mechanism. Methanol, being a suitable hydrogen carrier due to its high content and stability, holds promise in distributed energy systems [8,9]. According to Dumesic et al., low-temperature aqueous phase reforming (APR) demonstrated a more convenient device with lower energy consumption than methanol steam reforming. Furthermore, it effectively reduced the production of the noxious by-product CO [10]. Efficient hydrogen production occurs through APR at mild temperatures (220–270 ℃) and the appropriate amount of pressure (30–60 bar) [11]. Methanol APR generally involves two steps. Initially, the methanol molecule forms methoxy at the active metal site by breaking the OH bond. Subsequently, the formed methoxy group undergoes dehydrogenation to generate adsorbed H2 and CO*. Ideally, CO* reacts with hydrolyzed adsorbed hydroxyl groups to produce CO2 and H2 through the water gas shift (WGS) reaction (CO+H2O→CO2+H2). On the other hand, the CO* intermediate may also experience CO cleavage, leading to undesirable alkane formation (CO+3H2→H2O+CH4) [12,13]. Thus, for the APR process to be effective, the catalyst must demonstrate high activity in breaking CH bonds, the ability to promote subsequent WGS reactions and low methanation reaction activity. In research by Davda et al., Pt loaded onto SiO2 exhibited significant hydrogen selectivity in APR reactions involving ethylene glycol [14]. Platinum demonstrates the capability to dissociate methanol into CO* and H*. Employing catalyst support aids in metal dispersion adjustment for enhanced hydrogen yield. Shabaker et al. investigated various carriers for platinum in APR reactions, revealing that carbon supports yielded hydrogen comparably to Al2O3 [15]. Compared to other metal oxides, carbon materials possess a high specific surface area and chemical inertness, facilitating the enhancement of active metal site dispersion and catalyst stability [16,17]. However, the hydrophobicity of carbon materials poses challenges for the adsorption of reactants in APR. Enhancing catalytic reactions hinges on manipulating reactant and product concentrations near the active center. Elevating catalyst wettability serves as a catalyst for swift atom diffusion, enabling enriched reactants and subsequently bolstering reaction rates [18]. Maroto et al. employed an acid-base reaction method to modulate the hydrophilic-hydrophobic properties by altering the surface oxygen content through reactions between carbon and acid-base agents [19]. Wang et al. converted the ZIF-8 precursor into ZnO and NC to form an NC-encapsulated Cu/ZnO structure that exhibits favorable wettability and hydrothermal stability. They discovered that the activity of APR increased exponentially with the increase in catalyst wettability [17]. Although Pt-based catalysts are widely used in APR for their high activity, there are several problems to be solved. As a precious metal, the Pt faces constraints due to its limited reserves and high costs [7,20]. Moreover, Pt site is inclined to adsorb CO, an intermediate product of the APR reaction, resulting in the formation of a Pt-CO bond with strong interaction. At this stage, the adsorbed CO occupies the Pt active site, preventing the adsorption of methanol and its cleavage. This reduces the effectiveness of the catalyst and contributes to catalyst poisoning, which negatively affects hydrogen production [2,21,22]. Researchers have incorporated second metal as promoters to overcome these obstacles. This strategic integration serves a dual purpose: reducing costs and enhancing water dissociation. Additionally, it facilitates the adsorption of -OH groups on metal surfaces and assists in CO oxidation on Pt surfaces [23–26]. Mao synthesized lanthanum nickel perovskite oxides with different perovskite and loaded Pt, the catalyst possessed more abundant active OH groups, which beneficial for CO shift. Additionally, catalyst presented extremely excellent stability with only 7 % loss of its highest rate of hydrogen production after 315 h on stream [27]. Lin loaded Pt onto α-MoC, the α-MoC provided highly active sites for water dissociation, producing abundant surface hydroxyls. This catalyst showed outstanding hydrogen production activity and stability in the low-temperature APRM process [28]. Grisel et al. found that adding MnOx additives to the catalyst provides active oxygen species for CO oxidation, which aids in enhancing the oxidative activity of CO [29]. The WGS reaction, which is another rate-controlling step of APR, also plays a crucial role in determining the gas composition and the amount of hydrogen produced. Salai et al. applied detailed density functional theory (DFT) calculations and kinetic modeling to reveal the specific role of the three-phase boundary (TPB) in the WGS reaction. Their comprehensive analysis highlighted that bolstering TPB activity correlated with a reduction in CO adsorption strength at the Pt site on TPB. Moreover, it led to an increased presence of oxygen vacancies on TPB and facilitated water activation and deionization, elucidating the mechanisms underpinning enhanced WGS performance [30]. Therefore, in order to effectively enhance the WGS reaction, the catalyst performance can be adjusted by various modification methods. In addition to doping with alkali metals or alkali metal oxides as support to improve the alkalinity of the catalyst [6]. Strong hydrophilic supports can also be used to promote water adsorption and dissociation and directly introduce a second active metal to enhance the WGS reaction [31]. In this work, various strategies were employed to modify the surface hydrophilicity of carbon supports for the preparation of Pt-based catalysts. The methanol APR reaction was then performed under typical reaction conditions, as was the WGS reactivity. The surface properties of the catalysts and the valence states of the metal were analyzed using Raman, contact angle, XRD, XPS, and TEM characterizations. The performance of catalysts with different modification strategies was discussed, highlighting the influence of catalyst hydrophilicity on water adsorption and dissociation activity and corresponding APR reaction performances. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Activated carbon (200 mesh, 1200 m2/g), nitric acid (HNO3), potassium permanganate (KMnO4), manganese acetate (Mn(OAc)2), manganese nitrate (Mn(NO3)2), and H2PtCl6·6H2O were purchased from the McLean Chemical Reagent Factory. All reagents were analytical, pure-grade reagents without further purification. Activated carbon was used as a support after pretreatments. Specifically, activated carbon powder was dispersed in boiling deionized water and heated for 2 h, then vacuum filtered to separate the AC and washed to remove the ash. The washed-out AC was dispersed in 400 ml of 10 wt% HNO3 aqueous solution and reflowed at 80 ℃ for 5 h, filtered and washed to pH = 7, and then dried at 60 ℃ overnight. The processed AC was referred to as NC. The washed-out AC was modified using the water bath method using KMnO4 [32]. Specifically, 2 g AC was added to 200 ml of 20 wt% of KMnO4 aqueous solution and refluxed at 70 ℃ for 3 h, filtered, and washed with deionized water until the filtrate was colorless, and the obtained cake was dried overnight in a 60 ℃ oven. The processed AC was referred to as MnK/AC. The washed-out AC was modified by an equal volume impregnation method with Mn(NO3)2. Specifically, Mn(NO3)2 with a Mn content equivalent to MnK/AC was dissolved in deionized water to form an impregnating solution, and the volume of the solution should be close to the pore volume of AC. The solution was slowly added drop by drop to the carrier and held at room temperature for 12 h, then heated to 50 °C, stirred to a paste, and dried overnight in a 60 °C oven. The processed AC was referred to as Mn(NO3)2/AC. The washed-out AC was modified with Mn(OAc)2 and KMnO4, keeping the Mn content constant with MnK/AC. Usually, a certain amount of AC and Mn(OAc)2 was dissolved in 50 ml of deionized water and subjected to ultrasonic treatment for 2 h, and then KMnO4 was added to the solution and stirred at room temperature for 6 h, according to the equation to determine the reaction between Mn(OAc)2 and KMnO4. Finally, the mixture was filtered and washed several times in deionized water, and the cake was dried overnight in a 60 ℃ oven. The processed AC was referred to as Mn(OAc)2/AC. Pt/NC, PtMnK/AC, PtMnK/ACNM, and PtMnK/AC-AM were prepared using the initial wet impregnation method. The modified carriers, namely NC, MnK/AC, Mn(NO3)2/AC, and Mn(OAc)2/AC, were impregnated with H2PtCl6·6H2O solution, the nominal loading of Pt was fixed at 2 wt%. The solution was slowly added drop by drop to the carrier and kept at room temperature for 12 h, then heated to 50 °C, stirred to paste and dried overnight in a 60 °C oven. Subsequently, the sample was calcined under nitrogen at 350 °C for 3 h and then reduced under hydrogen flow at 250 ℃ for 2 h. To maintain consistency of variables, the same concentration of K ions as MnK/AC was added to all catalysts. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The surface defect of the catalyst was characterized by Raman spectroscopy (Renishaw, UK) with an excitation laser wavelength of 532 nm. The crystalline structure of the catalysts was characterized by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) on the X'Pert Pro-MPD (PANalytical, the Netherlands) using graphite monochromatic Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm) at 40 kV and 30 mA and the scan angle 2θ = 10–80°, the phase analysis was obtained by MDI Jade 6.0 software fitting with the Rietveld method. The contact angle of the catalyst was characterized by the sessile drop method (Kino SL 250, USA). The contact angle was determined by drawing a tangent close to the edge of the droplet. The surface of the chemical composition and elemental chemical valence state of the catalyst was characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) on the Escalab 250Xi (Thermo Fisher, USA) using an Al Kα X-ray radiation source. All peaks for indefinite carbon were calibrated using the C 1s peak with a binding energy of 284.8 eV. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) was conducted on JEM-2100F (JEOL, Japan), and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) was used to observe the elemental mappings of the catalyst. 2.3 Aqueous phase reforming of methanol The aqueous phase reforming reaction experiments were conducted in a 50 ml stainless-steel batch reactor. In a typical experiment, 20 ml of a 10 wt% solution of methanol and 200 mg of catalyst powder were added to the reactor. To remove any air from the reactor, argon gas was purged three times. The APR reaction was carried out under magnetic agitation at 400 rpm. The experiment was heated to 250 ℃ for 6 h. After the temperature dropped to room temperature, gas products were collected using an airbag, and the main components of the gaseous products were analyzed using GC-2014C (Shimadzu, Japan) equipped with a TDX-01 column and TCD detector. The liquid product contents were determined and qualified by HPLC (Waters e2695, Alliance, USA). The selectivity of hydrogen and gaseous carbon product (i = COx and CH4) were calculated as follow: n gas = V Gas P x i / RT Sel . The catalyst WGS activities of the catalyst were researched in the continuous flow reactor. A flow of 0.025 ml/min of water was injected into the reactor. The tests were carried out at 250 ℃ with an initial atmosphere of 10 vol.% CO/N2 (5 ml/min). The main components of the gaseous products were analyzed using GC-2014 C (Shimadzu, Japan), which was equipped with a TDX-01 column and TCD detector. The results are shown in Fig. 1 , which clearly shows distinct peaks in the Raman spectrum. These peaks are identified as the sp3-type disordered structure (D band) at 1360 cm−1 and the sp2-type ordered graphite structure (G band) at 1610 cm−1 within the carbon material. Significantly, the ID/IG peak area ratio is higher for Pt/NC (ID/IG = 0.89) compared to Pt/AC (ID/IG = 0.88). This indicates a higher incidence of defects in the HNO3-treated carbon supports [32]. Remarkably, PtMnK/ACNM (ID/IG = 0.85), PtMnK/AC-AM (ID/IG = 0.86), and PtMnK/AC (ID/IG = 0.84) catalysts exhibite significantly fewer carbon defects in comparison to Pt/AC (ID/IG = 0.89). However, this unexpected discovery contradicts the anticipated result of KMnO4's potent oxidation, which was conventionally presumed to generate various defects on activated carbon surfaces [33]. Instead, this deviation is attributed to the MnOx coverage, which effectively conceals most carbon defects. In addition, the Raman spectrum shows a distinct peak at 645 cm−1, which further strengthens the evidence for the presence of MnOx [34]. The improvement of catalytic reactions often involves changing the concentrations of the reactants or products in the vicinity of the active site. This was particularly relevant to the heterogeneous catalytic reaction of APR, which involves the absorption, transfer, and conversion of reactants, followed by the transfer and desorption of products [18]. Therefore, it was logical that boosting catalyst hydrophilicity would enhance the rapid diffusion of polar molecules within the reaction substrate. Such enrichment around the active site would foster higher reaction rate. Fig. 2 illustrates the contact angles that have been observed as a result of the different treatment strategies applied to the carbon supports. Young's equation elucidated the relationship between the contact angle of a liquid on a solid surface and the contrast in surface tension between solid-gas and solid-liquid interfaces [35]. Contact angles above 90° typically indicate the hydrophobicity of a surface. In this study, the contact angle of untreated Pt/AC is remarkably high at 103.5°, confirming its inherent hydrophobic properties. In contrast, activated carbon treated with nitric acid exhibits a contact angle of only 58.3°, suggesting the hydrophilicity of Pt/NC. The chemical and physical properties of a catalyst can be adjusted in order to modify the wettability of its surface. The observation of enhanced wettability in Pt/NC, as compared to Pt/AC, suggests superior specific structural or chemical attributes on the surface of Pt/NC. According to the Cassie-Baxter model, when a liquid comes into contact with a rough solid surface, a direct air layer is created between the liquid and the solid surface, thereby preventing the liquid from wetting the uneven solid surface entirely [36]. Despite exhibiting more defects than Pt/AC (as seen in Fig. 1(a)), Pt/NC demonstrates a lower contact angle, suggesting that its hydrophilicity extends beyond structural factors. It is reasonable to assume that the HNO3 treatment led to the formation of oxygen-containing groups on the carbon surface, which was an enhancement of the hydrophilicity [19]. In Fig. 2(c), (d) and (e) it is evident that activated carbons treated with three different sources of manganese exhibit hydrophilic properties, of which the KMnO4 treated samples exhibit the best hydrophilic properties for PtMnK/AC. This observed phenomenon extends beyond the inherent hydrophilicity of MnOx. In particular, the KMnO4 treatment increases the overall hydrophilicity of the carbon support by precipitating the formation of oxygen-containing groups on the surface of the activated carbon [37,38]. Fig. 3 presents the XRD patterns of catalysts treated by different methods. Initially, the untreated Pt/AC catalyst exhibits a broad diffraction peak at 26.2°, indicating an inherent disordered structure within the untreated activated carbon material. However, after the treatment process, this prominent diffraction peak was significantly reduced in the activated carbon samples, which is in consistent agreement with the spectroscopic results obtained by Raman spectroscopy [32]. In addition, the XRD profiles of both Pt/AC and Pt/NC samples show faint characteristic PtO2 peaks at 2θ of 40.1°. Notably, the catalyst treated with nitric acid displays an almost imperceptible peak, indicating a significant improvement in metal dispersion across the activated carbon substrate [7]. The XRD patterns of each catalyst with different sources of manganese treatment methods show peaks of Mn3O4 at 2θ = 18.0°, 28.9°, 32.4°, 36.1°, 44.4°, 58.5°, and 60.7° (PDF#97-006-8174). In the process of the PtMnK/AC catalyst, MnO2 was spontaneously deposited on carbon by redox reaction with the carbon in an aqueous solution of KMnO4. Carbon functions as a reducing agent in a redox reaction with KMnO4, This reaction can be represented by the formula of 4MnO4 −+3C+H2O→4MnO2+CO3 2−+2HCO3 − [39]. However, the characteristic peak of MnO2 was absent from the XRD pattern, which suggests a phase transition and valence decrease from Mn (IV) to Mn (II) and Mn (III) due to the reducibility of activated carbon. The physical and chemical properties of catalysts were investigated through X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) to analyze the effects of various manganese sources. Fig. 4 displays the catalyst where there are two clear peaks observed at the binding energies of Mn 2p3/2 and Mn 2p1/2 pertaining to Mn 2p. These peaks exhibit binding energy values of 641.2 eV and 652.8 eV, respectively. The presence of manganese oxides is indicated by the difference of 11.6 eV between the binding energies of these two peak [40]. As indicated in Fig. 4(b)–(d), further Lorentz/Gauss deconvolution of Mn 2p peaks results in Mn(Ⅱ) (641.2 and 652.9 eV), Mn(Ⅲ) (642.6 and 653.2 eV) and Mn(Ⅳ) (644.4 and 654.5 eV) valence states, indicating the existence of multiple forms of manganese oxides [41]. Furthermore, the Mn 2p satellite signature peak is distinctly noticeable at approximately 647 eV, which facilitates the identification of MnO and Mn2O3. The reduced binding energy of Mn in PtMnK/AC suggests that the mean valence state of Mn in PtMnK/AC is low. According to the principle of electrical neutrality, the presence of Mn3+ and Mn2+ is closely associated with oxygen vacancy and the highest molar fraction observed in PtMnK/AC suggests the presence of abundant oxygen vacancy [42]. The adsorbed oxygen species are produced through the activation of oxygen molecules by the oxygen vacancy of metal oxides. Therefore, the molar fraction of adsorbed oxygen increases with the number of oxygen vacancies. Fig. 5(b) shows the XPS of O 1s. The O 1s XPS spectrum of the catalyst reveals three distinct peaks, including the M-O peak at 529 eV, which represents the binding of the oxygen atom with the metal, and the -OH peak at 532 eV, which is associated with the hydroxyl group of water molecules adsorbed on the surface. The Pt/AC catalyst primarily contains M-O and -OH [43]. The catalyst with Mn metal addition exhibits a peak attributed to oxygen vacancy at the defect site of low oxygen coordination at 531 eV. The peak area of PtMnK/AC at 531 eV is more prominent, indicating that this catalyst contained more oxygen vacancies than the other samples. From the Pt 4f spectra in Fig. 5(a), it can be found that compared to the Pt/AC catalyst, the addition of Mn species causes a shift in binding energy, suggesting that the electron transfer from Pt to Mn occurred. This highlights the influence of the different treatments of the manganese source on the electron transfer on the catalyst surface, which could be effectively concluded by XPS. Besides, it can be observed that the Pt 4f binding energy of PtMnK/AC, which used potassium permanganate as a manganese source, was higher than that of PtMnK/ACNM (manganese nitrate) and PtMnK/AC-AM (manganese acetate). This suggests that a stronger interaction between Pt and Mn species in PtMnK/AC is achieved. By comparing the TEM images at low magnification of Pt/AC and PtMnK/AC in Fig. 6 , it is observed that the average particle size decreased significantly from 3.56 nm to 2.78 nm after KMnO4 addition. It is due to the K + residue resulting from the KMnO4 treatment process, and similar effects are observed using other types of potassium salts [32]. EDS was utilized to examine the distribution of Pt, Mn, and K on PtMnK/AC, and the distinct bright spots of different colors corresponded to C (white), Pt (yellow), Mn (green), and K (red). These images indicate a well-dispersed distribution of Pt, Mn, and K on the surface of AC, suggesting the absence of aggregation during the preparation process. It also implies that the KMnO4 treatment positively influenced the anchoring and dispersion of metals on the carbon support caused by the surface modification by its strong oxidation property. 3.2 Catalytic performances of methanol APR Methanol aqueous phase reforming experiments were conducted in a batch reactor applying as-synthesized catalysts with equivalent Pt amount but different carbon support modified with nitric acid, manganese nitrate, manganese acetate, and potassium permanganate, respectively. The comparison of unmodified Pt/AC catalyst and HNO3 modified Pt/NC catalyst showed that the hydrophilic functional groups on the surface of the carbon supports can improve the hydrophilicity and by using three different manganese raw materials to modify the carbon supports, it is found that KMnO4 with strong oxidizing property can react with AC introduce hydrophilic functional groups to improve the hydrophilicity of the carbon supports. As depicted in Fig. 7 , the hydrogen yield on the Pt/AC catalyst for the APR reaction was 23.43 %. The data set present here were replicate of 3 data points with a% error ±5. In contrast, when activated carbon was treated with 10 wt% HNO3 and loaded with an equivalent amount of Pt metal for the APR reaction, the hydrogen yield increased to 26.39 %. Based on the Raman and XRD results, HNO3 treatment, as a typical method to the modification of carbon support, resulting in an increase in surface defects on carbon support, which enhanced both the stability and dispersion of Pt metal particles [37]. Moreover, despite introducing structural defects by oxidation and calcination processes, it also improved the hydrophilic properties of carbon support by incorporating hydrophilic functional groups containing highly electronegative oxygen atoms onto their surface. The effective dissociation of H2O is a key step that determining reaction rates and gas product selectivity of the methanol APR reaction. As a typical aqueous phase reforming catalyst, Pt/AC catalyst shows high methanation activity, which is because the active site of Pt is easy to form strong Pt-CO bond with the intermediate CO. The strong interaction between Pt-CO makes it difficult for CO to desorb quickly and occupy the active site of Pt, preventing further adsorption of methanol and its cracking. At the same time, in the hydrogen atmosphere, a side reaction that leads to the CO bond break and hydrogenation to form alkanes, which not only leads to an increased methanation activity that consumes hydrogen but also limits the WGS reaction rate that can extract hydrogen, resulting in a decrease in hydrogen yield in the final products. Therefore, by modifing the surface of carbon support, the improvement of its hydrophilicity is beneficial for the adsorption and dissociation of H2O molecules, and H2 is produced effeciently by WGS reaction with CO intermediates, while the alkane selectivity is reduced accordingly. It was discovered that the addition of Mn species to Pt-based catalyst had a greater catalytic activity than that of single metal Pt catalyst. Mn as a promoter improved the catalytic activity and was beneficial to the oxidation reaction [25]. By introducing Mn(NO3)2, Mn(OAc)2 and KMnO4 to pretreat activated carbon can efficiently modify its surface properties. It can be clearly observed that compared to the unmodified Pt/AC catalyst, the PtMnK/AC catalyst showed a slight increase in H2 selectivity, but the methanol conversion increased from 22.69 % to 49.09 %, and the hydrogen production increased from 41.95 mmol to 92.83 mmol, as well as a significant increase in hydrogen yield. PtMnK/ACNM and PtMnK/AC-AM catalysts that with the same contents of Mn and K with KMnO4-treated PtMnK/AC catalyst was treated with Mn(NO3)2 and Mn(OAc)2 respectively, slightly reduced methane selectivity and increased hydrogen yield in APR reaction (Fig. 7). It signifies that the strong oxidation of KMnO4 properties that imroving hydrophilicity of the carbon support plays a more important role in promoting hydrogen production by accelarating H2O adsorption and dissociation. Meanwhile, based on Raman spectra and contact angle characterization results, the strong oxidation of KMnO4, similar to HNO3, led to the introduction of hydrophilic functional groups on the surface of activated carbon. Additionally, it introduced hydrophilic MnOx on its surface. This renders the highest hydrogen yield on PtMnK/AC catalyst due to its superior hydrophilic surface. However, treatment with weakly acidic manganese precursor Mn(NO3)2 and acidic manganese precursor Mn(OAc)2 resulted in limited changes to the surface properties of activated carbon. The results of XPS spectra show that the Mn(Ⅲ): Mn(Ⅱ) ratio of PtMnK/AC catalyst is the highest, and the valence change from Mn(Ⅳ) to Mn(Ⅲ) and Mn(Ⅱ) made it easy to reduce and form active sites. Simultaneously, the APR results for all catalysts demonstrated an improvement in CO2 selectivity with the addition of Mn metal, with the highest increase observed in the PtMnK/AC catalyst at 97.2 %. This suggested that Mn addition facilitated the conversion of CO to CO2 by increasing CO oxidation activity in WGS reaction [44]. The comparison of reaction conditions and catalytic APR performances among previous literatures and this work is made in Table 1 . PtMnK/AC catalysts showed higher methanol conversion than Ni-based and La-based catalysts, which proved the superiority of Pt as the typical APR active metal. Despite the high reaction temperature (250 ℃), the H2 selectivity of PtMnK/AC in this work was generally higher than that of other types of catalysts, which also implied that the improvement of hydrophilic properties promotes the WGS reaction on PtMnK/AC catalysts. One of the main benefits of APR is its capacity to generate three moles of hydrogen per mole of methanol, with one mole resulting from the WGS reaction. Although both CO and CO2 hydrogenation to form hydrocarbons are favorable under APR reaction conditions that generally consume H2. therefore, the improvement of WGS reaction activity is essential for increase H2 selectivity. Herein, a series of WGS reaction was performed on these catalysts in a fixed bed reactor and H2, CO, and CO2 concentrations were analyzed using chromatography. As is shown in Table 2 , it can be found that the low conversion rate of CO on the Pt/AC catalyst is only 35.45 %, which was attributed to the strong adsorption between the Pt metal and CO, which prevented the methanol adsorption and dehydrogenation on Pt sites. For the Pt/NC catalyst treated with nitric acid, a higher CO conversion rate of 41.96 % is obtained. Based on previous characterization results, it can be inferred that Pt/NC possesses better hydrophilic properties because it facilitates the adsorption and dissociation of H2O molecules. Moreover, upon the addition of Mn species to the catalyst by using Mn(NO3)2 and Mn(OAc)2 as precursors, significant increases in CO conversion were observed, indicating that manganese oxide in catalyst contributes to the oxidation of CO into CO2 due to its abundant oxygen vacancies [50]. The highest CO conversion rate of 84.48 % was achieved over PtMnK/AC catalyst treated with KMnO4, and more H2 and CO2 are obtained in the gas products, indicating the highest WGS reaction activity inspite of the same content of Mn with PtMnK/ACNM and PtMnK/AC-AM catalysts. This is in consistent with the results of APR reaction proposed before. The main reason that can be inferred is due to the combination effect of surface modification of AC support by improving its hydrophilicity and the promotion of manganese oxide, which enhances the WGS reaction activity as well as APR reaction of methanol, and promotes hydrogen production. As is analyzed, the KMnO4 modification strategy gives the catalyst an enhanced APR activity and hydrogen yield, which mainly reflects in the improvement of the rate determining step, WGS reaction (Fig. 8 ). It is widely accepted that the WGS reaction proceeds through two possible mechanisms: a redox mechanism and an association mechanism [51]. Both mechanisms involve the adsorption of reactant H2O and CO gas phase molecules onto the catalyst surface, with H2O being completely dissociated into H* and OH* species. For carbon-supported Pt-based catalysts, although Pt metal exhibits high CH bond breaking ability, the carbon support not only remains inert but also demonstrates weak adsorption capacity for H2O. Consequently, this leads to a high selectivity of CH4 on Pt/AC catalysts. The key to enhancing the APR performance of carbon-supported Pt-based catalysts lies in improving its hydrophilicity and dissociation capacity of water. It is reasonable to assume that enhancing the water molecule adsorption capacity on activated carbon support can be achieved by treating it with a strong oxidizing agent, KMnO4, and introducing hydrophilic oxygen-containing functional groups on its surface as well. Besides, KMnO4 treatment also helps to dope K atom on its surface, which may be conducive to promote H2O dissociation by enabling direct K-O bonding with oxygen-containing substances during the transition state [52]. Concurrently, an augmented occurrence of oxygen vacancies in PtMnK/AC advances the adsorption process of H2O. These molecules dissociate into hydrogen and active oxygen species on oxygen vacancies. Consequently, the CO molecules adsorbed on the surface of Pt react with them to generate CO2, instead of hydrogenating with H2 to form CH4. And then, CO intermediates that originally occupied Pt sites will desorb from its and facilitate further adsorption and dehydrogenation of methanol. 4 Conclusions In this study, carbon supported catalysts using various treatment strategies were prepared and their properties and APR reaction performances were analyzed and compared. Specially, KMnO4 with strong oxidation property can reacts with AC and improves its hydrophilicity. It is demonstrated that the KMnO4-modified catalyst PtMnK/AC exhibited superior hydrogen yield (51.37 %) but less alkane selectivity compared to the unmodified Pt/AC catalyst and HNO3 modified Pt/NC catalyst. This improvement can be attributed to the favorable hydrophilicity of the PtMnK/AC catalyst, which facilitated the adsorption and dissociation of H2O in the WGS reaction, which is regarded as the rate determining step of APR reaction. Besides, the promoting effects of manganese oxide on the CO oxidation to form CO2 were also verified. It is concluded that with a simple pretreatment method using KMnO4 cannot only modify the surface properties, hydrophilicity in particular, but also introduce Mn as promoter, which increase methanol cracking activity and hydrogen yield in methanol APR. This provides a new regulating strategy of the carbon supported catalyst and an understanding in promoting water adsorption and dissociation activity by enhancing hydrophilicity of carbon support. coredata.dc:description: The production of hydrogen through the aqueous phase reforming of biomass-derived oxygenates has broad application prospects in distributed hydrogen energy systems. Activated carbon is commonly employed as a catalyst support in catalytic aqueous phase reforming due to its high surface area and hydrothermal stability. Nevertheless, its hydrophobicity hinders the efficient adsorption of water molecules, which affects the activity of the aqueous phase reforming reaction. In this study, catalysts using carbon as support with varying hydrophilicity were synthesized using nitric acid and potassium permanganate as modifiers. The efficiency of these catalysts was then examined in the aqueous phase reforming reaction of methanol and the water gas shift reaction, respectively. The impact of the hydrophilicity of the support on the reaction performances was examined with diverse characterization techniques. The results demonstrated that the PtMnK/AC catalyst exhibited 1.2 times the hydrogen production yield compared to the conventional Pt/AC catalyst, indicating that enhancing the hydrophilicity of the support promoted the water gas shift reaction while limiting methanation side reactions in methanol aqueous phase reforming. The effective interaction between hydrophilic surfaces and oxygen vacancies enhances the catalyst's capability to dissociate H2O and react with CO* intermediates to generate more hydrogen, which is regarded as the rate determining step of methanol aqueous phase reforming.
coredata.dc:title: Efficient hydrogen production by methanol aqueous phase reforming over KMnO4 modified PtMnK/AC catalyst: Regulating the hydrophilicity of carbon support
